summary: This document is a series of internal U.S. Department of Justice emails from June 18, 2020, discussing challenges in obtaining an interview with Prince Andrew as a material witness in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation via a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to the United Kingdom. The emails reveal the UK Home Office's reluctance to proceed due to perceived lack of predication regarding Prince Andrew's knowledge or involvement, concerns about potential judicial review litigation, and a breakdown in trust between the U.S. prosecution team and Prince Andrew's lawyers (Blackfords).

persons.name: Andrew
persons.context: Referred to as 'Prince Andrew' in context, he is the subject of the U.S. DOJ's MLAT request to the UK for an interview regarding his knowledge of or involvement in Jeffrey Epstein's criminal conduct.

persons.name: Dawn Browne
persons.context: A UKCA official who communicated the Home Office's position on the MLAT request, explained concerns about judicial review, and liaised with the U.S. prosecution team.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.context: The lawyer from Blackfords representing Prince Andrew, who corresponded with the U.S. case team regarding voluntary cooperation and stated his client was willing to assist.

persons.name: Philomena Creffield
persons.role: Deputy Director & Head of UK Central Authority
persons.context: Senior UK official involved in the MLAT discussions, corresponded with U.S. officials regarding the status of the request and next steps.

persons.name: Julian Gibbs
persons.context: A UKCA official copied on the email correspondence regarding the Material Witness PA MLAT request.

persons.name: Margaret Browne
persons.context: A UKCA official (likely Dawn Browne) copied on the email correspondence regarding the Material Witness PA MLAT request.

persons.name: Amanda J. Chadwick
persons.context: A U.S. DOJ Attaché based at the U.S. Embassy in London, who sent the final email formally requesting the UKCA to move forward with the MLAT without further delay.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the criminal investigation for which Prince Andrew's testimony is sought as a material witness.

connections.description: Bloxsome, from the law firm Blackfords, is acting as legal counsel for Prince Andrew, communicating his position on voluntary cooperation with the U.S. investigation.
U.S. DOJ Attaché and UKCA official corresponding and negotiating the terms and justification for the MLAT request regarding Prince Andrew.
The email describes a 'significant mutual lack of trust' between the U.S. case team and Prince Andrew's lawyers, hindering voluntary cooperation.
The U.S. DOJ is seeking to question Prince Andrew about his knowledge of or involvement in Epstein's criminal conduct.

events.title: UK Home Office Resists MLAT Request for Prince Andrew
events.description: The UK Home Office informs the U.S. DOJ that they will not process the MLAT request for Prince Andrew unless provided with further specifics about his knowledge or involvement in criminal conduct, which the U.S. states they do not have.

events.title: Correspondence Between U.S. Team and Prince Andrew's Lawyers
events.description: A series of communications occurs between the U.S. prosecution team and Gary Bloxsome of Blackfords regarding the possibility of a voluntary interview with Prince Andrew, ultimately leading to a breakdown in trust.

events.title: U.S. DOJ Formally Requests UKCA to Proceed with MLAT
events.description: U.S. DOJ Attaché Amanda J. Chadwick sends a formal email to the UKCA, stating that efforts to obtain a voluntary interview are exhausted and requesting the UKCA to move forward with the MLAT request without further delay.

keyFacts: The UK Home Office refused to process the U.S. MLAT request to interview Prince Andrew, citing a lack of predication regarding his knowledge or involvement in Epstein's crimes.
The U.S. prosecution team and Prince Andrew's lawyers (Blackfords) had developed a 'significant mutual lack of trust,' making a voluntary interview outside the MLAT process impossible.
The UKCA was concerned that approving the MLAT would lead to a judicial review lawsuit from Blackfords, arguing the Home Office failed to exhaust avenues for voluntary cooperation first.
Prince Andrew's legal team had stated as recently as early June 2020 that he was willing to voluntarily assist the investigation, which the UKCA cited as a reason to delay the MLAT.
The U.S. DOJ argued that requiring exhaustion of informal avenues before an MLAT conflicted with the US-UK treaty and would affect many future cases.
